title: What are the theories behind hypnotism and magnetic sleep, according to medical practitioners of the past?
first_phrase: In this text, the author explores various theories of hypnotism, including those of German researcher Preyer, English physician Carpenter, and French doctor Bernheim. The author also examines the theories of Mesmer and his followers, who believed that a universal fluid was responsible for the effects of hypnotism. Different methods for inducing hypnotic states are discussed, including the use of passes, fixation of the gaze, and the placement of objects. The author concludes by summarizing the wide variety of physical and psychological phenomena experienced by subjects in hypnotic states.

last_phrase: In conclusion, while there are diverging theories among doctors and scientists regarding the influence of the exporting attention and the existence of a magnetic fluid, it is clear that the science of magnetism is still in its early stages and many of its claims are not yet scientifically proven. Lucid somnambulism and the ability for remote suggestion are among the phenomena that still require further scrutiny before they can be accepted conclusively. However, new studies by some non-magnetism-believing doctors suggest that there may be more to this field than many previously thought, and that some of the seemingly miraculous claims of magnetists may warrant further investigation.
